metadata.case_name: Appellants (Lessees of Salt Works) v. Respondents (Agarias)

facts.text: Appellants are lessees of Salt Works from erstwhile State of Dharangadhara and hold licence for manufacture of salt on the land.
Appellants require salt for manufacture of chemicals; part used in Chemical Works at Dharangadhara, remainder sold to outsiders.
Appellants employ Salt Superintendent who supervises Salt Works and manufacture of salt.
Appellants maintain railway line, sidings, drinking water storage, and grocery shop where agarias purchase on credit.
Salt manufactured from rain water impregnated with saline matter; operations seasonal, commence in October post-monsoon, end in June.
Area parceled into plots called pattas in four parallel rows intersected by railway lines; each agaria allotted a patta, usually same year after year; extensive pattas to two agarias in partnership.
At allotment, appellants pay Rs. 400/- per patta for initial expenses.
Agarias level lands, enclose and sink wells; Salt Superintendent examines density of water in wells.
Brine brought to surface, collected in condensers until certain density; flowed into pattas until transformed into crystals.
Pans prepared by agarias to standards tested by Salt Superintendent; crystals tested for quality before collection allowed.
Crystals loaded into railway wagons, transported to depots, tested; if quality right, agarias paid Rs. 0-5-6 per maund.
Rejected salt belongs to appellants; agarias cannot remove or sell salt.
End of season accounts settle advances, grocery debts; balance paid to agarias.
Agarias work with families on pattas; free to engage extra labour, pay them themselves; appellants have nothing to do with it.
No prescribed hours, no muster roll, no control on days worked; no rules for leave/holidays; free to leave if arrangements made for salt manufacture.
In 1950, disputes arose between agarias and appellants on conditions of engagement.
Government of Saurashtra referred disputes to Industrial Tribunal by letter dated November 5, 1951.
Appellants contested: agarias independent contractors, not workmen; reference without jurisdiction under s.10 Act.
Tribunal held preliminary issue on August 30, 1952: agarias workmen, reference intra vires.
Appellants appealed to Labour Appellate Tribunal (Appeal No. 302 of 1952); sought stay, then moved High Court of Saurashtra in M.P. No. 70 of 1952 under Arts. 226/227 to quash reference.
High Court stayed Tribunal proceedings; Labour Appellate Tribunal dismissed appeal on September 27, 1953, leaving to High Court.
High Court by judgment January 8, 1954 agreed agarias are workmen under s.2(s), dismissed writ; granted certificate under Art.133(1)(c).

Evidence of Salt Superintendent: panholders allotted by oral agreement; no control over hours/days/sickness/leaving; no control over labourers/wages; supervision limited to quality per company/Govt standards; panholders are contractors.
Clause 6 of agreement: agarias bind to work per advice/instructions of officers on brine drawing/salt production; default allows annulment.

Evidence of Shiva Daya (agaria): company supervises enclosures/wells; measures density; tests condenser brine; inspects patta bottom; inspects salt formation; supervises draining; instructs fresh brine flow.

legal_issues.text: Whether the agarias working in the Salt Works at Kuda in the Rann of Cutch are workmen within the meaning of the term as defined in s.2(s) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

petitioner_arguments.text: Agarias are independent contractors, not workmen; no relationship of employer-employee as no right of control over manner of work.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(s) Industrial Disputes Act, 1947; principles from English cases on control test

petitioner_arguments.text: Piece-work payment (Rs. 0-5-6 per maund of quality salt), no fixed hours/days, no obligation to work specific periods.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Absence of wages basis indicates no employer-employee relation

petitioner_arguments.text: Agarias engage and pay own labour; appellants no control over them.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Independent contractors engage others to work

petitioner_arguments.text: Supervision limited to quality testing, not manner of work.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Contract for services, not of service

petitioner_arguments.text: Reference by State without jurisdiction as no industrial dispute involving workmen.

respondent_arguments.text: Relationship is employer-employee; pure question of fact decided by Tribunal with evidence; High Court cannot interfere under Arts.226/227.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ebrahim Aboobakar v. Custodian General; findings of fact not to be disturbed if supported by evidence

respondent_arguments.text: Supervision and control by appellants over all stages of manufacture from beginning to end.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Control test including instructions per Clause 6

court_reasoning.text: Essential condition for workman: employed in industry with employer-employee relationship; prima facie test is right of control over what work and manner of doing it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Control test from authorities; varies by business nature

court_reasoning.text: Distinction contract of service (control manner) vs. for services; but not universal - integration into business also relevant; captain of ship example.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cites Stevenson, Cassidy, Short v. Henderson, Mersey Docks

court_reasoning.text: Evidence shows supervision/control at all stages: density tests, pan preparation, crystal quality, etc.; Clause 6 binds to instructions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Materials support Tribunal finding; not no evidence

court_reasoning.text: Piece-work payment not decisive; can be servant paid by job.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cites Sadler v. Henlock, Blake v. Thirst, Halsbury

court_reasoning.text: Engaging assistants does not make workman into contractor if personally works; agarias professional labourers working with families.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cites Halsbury, Grainger v. Aynsley etc.; distinction: workman works personally

court_reasoning.text: Practical difficulties in applying rules not deterrent if definition fulfilled; Tribunal to consider in merits.

holdings.text: Agarias are workmen within s.2(s) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction contract for services vs. of service: control what and how

precedents_cited.case_name: Stevenson, Jordan and Harrison Ltd. v. Macdonald and Evans
precedents_cited.relevance: Control test not universal; integration into business
Control not always exercised; ordinary meaning of contract of service

precedents_cited.case_name: Short v. J. W. Henderson, Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Indicia of contract of service; modern conditions affect but control key

precedents_cited.case_name: Mersey Docks and Harbour Board v. Coggins Griffith (Liverpool) Ltd. and Another
precedents_cited.relevance: Authority to control manner of execution
Degree of control determines; question of fact by circumstances

precedents_cited.case_name: Ebrahim Aboobakar v. Custodian General of Evacuee Property
precedents_cited.relevance: Writ not to correct errors within jurisdiction; facts not disturbed

precedents_cited.case_name: Performing Right Society Ltd. v. Mitchell and Booker (Palais de Danse)
precedents_cited.relevance: Mixed fact/law per one view, but generally pure fact
Piece-work can be servant if control retained
Piece-work irrelevant if worker not contractor
Workman personally working not excluded by assistance

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of workman; reference of disputes; requires employment relation with control

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court writ jurisdiction; certificate for appeal; no interference with factual findings

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed. The Supreme Court upholds the Industrial Tribunal and High Court findings that agarias are workmen under s.2(s) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, based on evidence of control and supervision.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; proceedings before Tribunal to continue

key_quotes.text: 'The essential condition of a person being a workman within the terms of this definition is that he should be employed to do the work in that industry... Unless a person is thus employed there can be no question of his being a workman.'
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: 'The prima facie test for the determination of the relationship between master and servant is the existence of the right in the master to supervise and control the work done by the servant not only in the matter of directing what work the servant is to do but also the manner in which he shall do his work.'
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: 'We are of opinion that far from there being no evidence to support the conclusion reached by the Industrial Tribunal there were materials on the record on the basis of which it could come to the conclusion that the agarias are not independent contractors but workmen within the meaning of the Act.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects petitioner's no-evidence argument; upholds findings
